title: My toddler tried to "help" me make cookies and it was a disaster (but cute)
self_text: Okay, so I thought involving my 2-year-old in baking would be a fun bonding experience. HUGE mistake. Flour *everywhere*. Sprinkles embedded in the dog's fur. And he decided the cookie dough tasted better *on his head* than in his tummy. The cookies themselves look‚Ä¶abstract. But honestly? Seeing him covered in everything and giggling uncontrollably made it worth the mess. Anyone else have baking adventures with their little ones gone wrong? Send wine (and cleaning tips).

title: My toddler tried to ‚Äúhelp‚Äù me make cookies‚Ä¶ send coffee.
self_text: Okay, so I thought a Saturday morning baking session with my 2-year-old would be *adorable*. It was not. Flour EVERYWHERE. Sprinkles in her hair, on the dog, embedded in the carpet. She tasted every ingredient (even the baking soda ‚Äì thankfully a small amount). The dough now has glitter in it because "cookies need sparkle!" And honestly? They look less like cookies and more like abstract art. Send help (and caffeine). Anyone else have baking disasters with toddlers?

title: My toddler tried to "help" me make lasagna and it was a disaster (but also kinda cute)
self_text: So I decided to tackle lasagna tonight - ambitious, I know with a 2 year old running around. Big mistake. He insisted on ‚Äústirring‚Äù which resulted in sauce EVERYWHERE. On him, the floor, the dog‚Ä¶ everywhere but the bowl. Then he started adding random spices directly from the jar. I salvaged what I could, but honestly? Pretty sure half the seasoning ended up in the dish. It probably tastes like regret layered with ricotta. Send wine (and maybe a hazmat team). Anyone else have similar kitchen adventures?

title: My toddler discovered the joy of "helping" with dinner...send wine.

Apparently, a two-year-old‚Äôs idea of helping involves flinging uncooked pasta at the dog, attempting to stir the sauce with a toy car, and declaring all the meatballs ‚Äútoo spicy‚Äù before launching them across the kitchen. The floor is covered in noodles, the dog looks traumatized, and I'm pretty sure I just ate a rogue piece of penne off my shoe. Send help (and maybe a bottle of Cabernet). Anyone else survive a toddler ‚Äúcooking session‚Äù?

title: My toddler tried to "help" me make lasagna and it was‚Ä¶an experience.

title: My toddler tried to "help" me make cookies and it was a disaster (but also kinda cute)
